summary: Based on a story by famed science fiction writer Philip K. Dick, "Minority Report" is an action-detective thriller set in Washington D.C. in 2054, where police utilize a psychic technology to arrest and convict murderers before they commit their crime. Tom Cruise plays the head of this Precrime unit and is himself accused of the future murder of a man he hasn't even met.

Im Jahr 2054 liegt die Mordrate in Washington D.C bei null. Grund dafür sind die sogenannten Precogs. Diese können in die Zukunft sehen und die Polizei kann dadurch Morde verhindern die passieren würde. Der Chief John Anderton (Tom Cruise) wird selber verdächtig einen Mord durchzuführen und wird dabei von Detective Danny Witwer (Colin Farell) gejagt. Er will herausfinden, ob die Precogs sich irren können und möchte verhindern das er den Mord begeht.
Was mir nicht gefählt ist das Bild in einigen Stellen. Die ersten halbe Stunde ca und zwischen durch auch mal wieder ist das Bild sehr hell und der Hintergrund auch und das sieht nicht schön aus. Es gibt einige Effekte die nicht gut gealtert sind. Es gibt einige Szen die in anderen Medien auch Verwendung finden. In Detroit Become Human ist die Art wie der drogensüchtige Detective Beweise sammelt ähnlich, genauso wie der Charakter John Anderton. Die Szene, wo John blind ist finde ich sehr gut gemacht da sie auch realistisch gemacht wurde.Der Film setzt seinen Humor gut ein und es ist nicht zu viel davon Vorhanden das es nervt oder unpassend wirkt. Ich finde den Film gut, aber es gibt bessere Filme im Science-Fiction Genre.

Is there a free will or is future deterministic? is the key question Spielberg is asking in this fast-paced thriller. The movie is looking at this philosophical question by examining the near-future pre-crime department, where the character of Tom Cruise has to make a choice whether to kill or break a prediction. 

Pros - an interesting concept, combined with some data privacy aspects raised in the movie, which are however only teased but not fully explored. Fast-paced and action-packed.

Cons - lots and lots of CGI that in some places did not age well. But even disregarding CGI, the movie does not provide a viewer with an opportunity to come to their own conclusion on the key question, and quite inelegantly resolves it in the finale.

The characters seem one-dimensional and generic, with one or two straightforward motivation and lacking complexity.

All in all, a good movie to watch but would not come back to it.

Whats as impressive, are the VFX for 2002, they really hold up and create a perfect world building. Without a doubt, Minority Report is one of the best films in Tom Cruise's biography. The actor managed to combine drama and action in his role, the character is fully revealed with its advantages and disadvantages, and he really wants to empathize.

Other roles are also filled with excellent actors. Max von Sydow played the classic role of senior mentor and part-time evil genius, which he did flawlessly. Colin Farrell evoked ambivalent feelings - at first you feel hostility towards him (due to a conflict with the positive hero of Tom Cruise), and closer to the final you openly worry about him and sympathize. Samantha Morton also performed well as a seer. The actress gave herself completely to her character and realistically showed the seer's behavior in the terrible conditions of the crime prevention system.

The dissenting opinion looks at one breath right up to the finale. A captivating plot, excellent acting and directing, brilliant special effects from the ILM studio will justify all your hopes for this fantastic thriller!

Steven Speilberg, Tom Cruise, Neal McDonahugh, Max von Sydow, and Collin Farrell adapt Philip K Dick’s prescient short story In the distant future of 2054 we have the ability to detect any crime before it's ever committed called PreCrime It's a perfect system and the calculations are so precise it's never wrong Arrests are revolutionized by the ‘halo’ device, placed around a pre-criminal’s head to subdue them and eventually become part of their cell But criminals are not placed in the prisons we might expect They are put into what looks like a chemically induced coma and left in pods stored in the ground, akin to coffins Their face is obstructed by their halo, replacing their identity and humanity with a looped vision of their crime Virtually murder is erased from society Until Cruise's Jon Anderton is accused of a crime he didn't actually commit with a man he's never met He's officially on the run until he can prove he innocence Did he really do it or is the system rigged? The title of the film actually refers to the sliver of of doubt in a supposed system that's meant to be reliable Doubts are unacceptable within such clinical perfection, and a minority report will be destroyed to remove evidence of fallibility If the nation knew, the whole system would collapse Yet it’s a system built on lies “The nation,” aptly described at one point as the “land of the blind,” is viewed as a homogenous mass of unsuspecting victims who must be protected from themselves with authoritarianism, no matter their own humanity Lives then become numbers, and zero murder is treated as an absolute good without consideration of the means to reach that end Even Speilberg says the best science fiction stories have the most dire warnings about civilization and the future It's true the internet is watching us now If they want to, they can see what sites you visit…The scary thing is, we’ll lose our right to privacy An ad will appear in the air around us, talking directly to us hence sponsors and advertising for VPN to avoid phishing etc. Data collection is an open secret, denied emphatically by the NSA for years leading up to the Snowden revelations, and even since In terms of predicting authoritarian tech the moviemakers nail some things down pretty well such as our touchscreen tech like motion capture and virtual reality, facial recognition, drones, and our system of incarceration For example manipulation of augmented reality environments is becoming more common, as Guangzhou City has used something called a ‘Digital Twin,’ which operates as an exact virtual copy of the city Many police departments in the US also use VR for training purposes, creating and exploring various hypothetical scenarios for their officers Being held prisoner without due process in a machine that disregards human rights like this accurately predicted the horrors of Guantanamo Bay; it was notorious for its unrestrained torture and unchecked detention of innocent prisoners US President Barack Obama pledged to close the camp once he entered office, yet failed to do so Trump signed an executive order to keep it open indefinitely, and current President Joe Biden’s review only brought the number of detainees down to 38 While there is still official intent to shut Guantanamo down, its persistence over two decades marks it as a symbol of institutionalised pre-determinism of guilt resembling the film here Also scans are not only used for criminal investigation, as retinal identification allows for transport payment and micro-tailored marketing The filmmakers make this future look lighter and softer despite the harsh job PreCrime still has to engage in, the score by John Williams is intense if at times odd, Cruise works brilliantly as per usual, the future tech is really inventive, and many of our predictions living in the future are spot-on Sure this didn't need to be 2 and a half hours but it is slick looking, very dystopian, and quite accurate of our real world in terms of crime, technology, and the pros and cons of enacting Justice It's true every living creature has one thing in common; its own survival especially when it comes to having genes predetermining future actions that'll make them good or bad Guilt is now frequently pre-determined based on individual profiles, unfettered access to our lives is facilitated by enhanced surveillance, and punishment is enacted without hesitation It's true our technological form of justice has met and even surpassed the authoritarian surveillance of its dystopia Sci-fi is an apt mode to explore the future, but the future is coming perpetually quicker It’s already gone by the time our predictions can be expressed 'Minority Report' is a bold ambitious entry by this talented director and Cruise as a man doubting a reliable system he once believed in isn't so pristine or top of the line Big themes matched solely by its endless influence on both film and real-world technology

I consider myself to be relatively tolerant of many things in movies. I can handle quite a bit, but there was something about this one that really did make me quite uncomfortable. I think it was my inner voice crying out that no matter what would happen in the future, it was unethical to punish someone for a crime they hadn't committed. And I stand by that still. While some believe that fate exist, there is nothing set in stone and you can change your fate. In fact, we do that with every choice we make in life. There is a lot that can trigger people here, a lot that triggered me even. The movie has a subplot where Anderton (Cruise) is desperately searching for whoever kidnapped his son and we are to believe that the son was murdered. I'm a bit embarrassed to say that now the scene that made me the most uncomfortable had to do with a simple surgery. I've watched House but there's one thing I can't handle when it comes to surgery and that's eyes. Weird but I was not quite prepared for a graphic eye removal surgery of the main character.

With all that said, let me make it clear that this is an incredible thriller. It was made by the legendary Stephen Spielberg and is based on a story by Philip K. Dick who also brought us sci-fi classics like Blade Runner. The characters are each developed and interesting. The visuals are absolutely stunning, everything seems to just be perfect and I can't in my right mind not recommend this movie. There is a lot of content that might make viewers uncomfortable but if you go in knowing that I don't think it would affect as much. The movie reminded me a little bit of (one of my favorite movies of all time) 1998's "Pleasantville". This perfect world where no one gets hurt. But in creating that perfect world, you take away people's ability to live. Of course, this is much darker than Pleasantville but it ties a lot in with the same philosophies of it. "Minority Report" is a fantastic movie, absolutely!

Minority Report is an exciting sci-fi thriller/film noir. The effects and some of the future elements haven't aged well. I found the scenes where Tom Cruise got encapsulated in a self-driving car and eluding capture in a high-speed chase, jumping from car tops on a vertical highway too reminiscent of the droid factory sequence and flying car chase in Attack of the Clones (which came out a month earlier in 2002). These scenes in both films felt sterile and cartoonish, and made me think nothing was really at stake, so I got bored. Special effects in old films, though sometimes unconvincing, had a charm that audiences today still appreciate, but CGI special effects don't seem to age as well.

Some sci-fi elements were prescient, particularly in the details, like the especially invasive targeted ads and people readily giving up their civil rights in the name of safety. Other things, less so, such as people still reading newspapers and the ubiquitous presence of mainstream media, and COPS still being on the air. Sci-fi movies tend to overshoot on technology, and miss social trends, but get enough details right to seem prophetic.

As a pot-boiler, Minority Report is fast-paced and intriguing enough its other miscalculations can be easily overlooked as you get engrossed in the movie and the 145-minute runtime speed by.
Some of this projected technology is just hard to watch now and the way it was futuristically shot doesn't exactly hold up.

There's an interesting premise, though it requires some suspense of realism. I can live with that but it's all just done pretty ridiculously. A lot of over-the-top dialogue. And why is the lighting so awful in just about every scene? It seems intentional but if there's a good reason for it, it's lost on me.

(Rest assured, this review has no spoilers) Minority Report is a great movie and a must-see for any sci-fi fans. One of Spielberg's most underrated works and good acting from Tom Cruise. The themes of predetermination, prevention of crime, and the role of the media are very multilayered, as is to be expected from an adaptation of a Philip K. Dick book. Spielberg invokes the ideas of tech noir well as his protagonist explores the idea of predestined crime and authoritarianism as we explore a postmodern society in the search of the Minority Report. One of my favorite scenes is when the main character goes to a memory hacker, who can not only create new memories for people but can also extract buried ones. Of course, the film has some issues, seeing as the pace of the book was not created for film; however, Spielberg more than makes do by transitioning the pace to that of an action movie while still keeping the philosophical complexities of the book.

A great sci-fi thriller in which Tom Cruise plays a cop who heads up a unit that fights "PreCrime"; crimes that have yet to occur but are foretold by a trio of technologically enhanced clairvoyants.

Directed by Steven Spielberg with his characteristic energy and flair, this is a proper, throw things at the screen, blow the budget, action spectacular but has an interesting plot to go with it, based as it is on a Philip K Dick story.
Samantha Morton plays a pivotal role as one of the psychics and, as is typical of her, gives a very convincing performance while Max von Sydow is his usual, watchable self as the political boss of the whole operation.
Minority Report is a good, old fashioned block buster that is still a thrilling and enjoyable way to pass a couple of hours.

Well done, sir. But what else would you expect from one of the masters of the genre but a taut, engrossing, consistently winning action thriller? Spielberg's Minority Report is a impressive in all aspects of filmmaking- the screenplay by Cohen & Frank; the casting of Cruise, Morton, McDonough, Farrell, and the legend that is Max Von Sydow; top notch production values. 
But the direction by Spielberg is so stellar. The tone appropriate for a futuristic sci-fi action thriller is set from the first scene, and we are held within the compelling bounds of this world of 'Pre-Crime' policing. We have the science of the 'Pre-cogs', the hyper-sensitive beings who see heinous crimes before they happened, but also holding the 'reports' of those crimes, even horrific murders, in what seem to be quite fragile psyches. 
The wonderful Samantha Morton is Agatha, the key and most 'sensitive' of the Pre-cogs. Her fear and her cries to "Run!" feel almost palpable.
Von Sydow is equal parts cool, detached, sinister, but also believable as a 'creator' of this game-changing form of crime detecting.
Then there's Cruise- for all his portrayals of the ultimate 'good guy', as the All-American 'hero', the early cheese-ball roles, Cruise is remarkable in these roles. His ability to pull-off the earnest, indefatigable soldier of sorts along with his impressive physical capacity make him ideal for this role as it does for the Mission Impossible movies. In April 2054, Washington, DC's prototype PreCrime police department stops murderers before they act, reducing the murder rate to zero percent. Murders are predicted using specialized mutated humans, called "Precogs", who "previsualize" crimes by receiving visions of the future. Would-be murderers are imprisoned in a benevolent virtual reality. The federal government is on the verge of adopting the controversial program nationwide. Since the disappearance of his son Sean, PreCrime Captain John Anderton (Tom Cruise) has separated from his wife Lara (Kathryn Morris) and became a drug addict. While United States Department of Justice agent Danny Witwer (Colin Farrell) is auditing the program, the Precogs generate a new prediction, stating Anderton will murder a man he does not know named Leo Crow in 36 hours. Anderton flees the area as Witwer begins a manhunt. Anderton seeks the advice of Dr. Iris Hineman (Lois Smith), the creator of PreCrime technology. She reveals that sometimes one of the Precogs, usually Agatha (Samantha Morton), has a different vision than the other two; a "minority report" of a possible alternate future. This has been kept a secret as it would damage the system's credibility. Anderton resolves to recover the minority report to prove his innocence...

Rotten Tomatoes critical consensus is, "Thought-provoking and visceral, Steven Spielberg successfully combines high concept ideas and high octane action in this fast and febrile sci-fi thriller." The website listed it among the best reviewed films of 2002. Some reviewers felt that Spielberg did not adequately tackle the issues he raised. The movie has inspired much discussion and analysis, the scope of which has been compared to the continuing analysis of Blade Runner. This discussion has advanced past the realm of standard film criticism. Slovenian philosopher Slavoj Žižek fashioned a criticism of the Cheney Doctrine by comparing its preemptive strike methodology to that of the film's PreCrime system. Richard Corliss of Time said it's "Spielberg's sharpest, brawniest, most bustling entertainment since Raiders of the Lost Ark". Mike Clark of USA Today felt it succeeded due to a "breathless 140-minute pace with a no-flab script packed with all kinds of surprises." Lisa Schwarzbaum of Entertainment Weekly praised the film's visuals,and Todd McCarthy of Variety complimented the cast's performances. Film scholar Warren Buckland recommended the film, but felt that the comedic elements—aside from Stormare's lines—detracted from the plot and undermined the film's credibility. Andrew Sarris of the New York Observer gave the film a negative review in which he described the script as full of plot holes, the car chases as silly, and criticized the mixture of futuristic environments with "defiantly retro costuming". The complexity of the storyline was also a source of criticism for Kenneth Turan of the Los Angeles Times, who considered the plot "too intricate and difficult to follow". Both Rosenbaum and Hoberman belittled the titular minority report as a "red herring". More positive reviews have seen it similarly, but referred to it as a "MacGuffin".

"Minority Report" was one of the best-reviewed films of 2002 and was nominated for several awards. It received an Academy Award nomination for Best Sound Editing, and eleven Saturn Award nominations, including Best Actor, Best Supporting Actor, and Saturn Award for Best Music, winning Best Science Fiction Film, Best Direction, Best Writing, and Best Supporting Actress. The film earned over $358 million worldwide against an overall budget of $142 million (including advertising). Over four million DVDs were sold in its first few months of home release. The most commonly criticized element of the film is its ending. The film has a more traditional "happy ending" which contradicts the tone of the rest of the picture. This has led to speculation that this ending is the product of John's imagination, caused by hallucinations from his forced coma after he is incarcerated. Minority Report is a Spielberg/Cruise collaboration that I've had my eye on for quite some time now due to the intriguing premise and my love for the Sci-Fi genre. Yes, there are aspects I liked, but the shortcomings(from my point of view) bogged down the experience considerably.

Let's point out what I liked: Tom Cruise. Say what you want about him, the guy is the epitome of a superstar, and I personally enjoy watching a lot of his movies. He's one of the few saving graces in here. The others being the story obviously, some of the visuals, and the last half hour. The unraveling of the antagonists conspiracy was slickly and satisfyingly unfolded in a flow-chart fashion. I enjoyed that as well.

Now onto my reservations. First being the lighting. Why they decided to make 80% of the movie look like it was filmed on the surface of the sun is beyond me. I get that it takes place in the future, and perhaps this choice was made to further convey that fact, but jeez, talk about an eyesore. The camera angles were solid at least. Then there's the frequent, out-of-place, bizarre humor which feels like an antithesis to what the premise SHOULD feel like. I don't want gags like an elderly man dropping a deuce, or perverted elderly women occurring within a movie about the futuristic ability to prevent murders before they occur. It just doesn't mesh well and causes the film to feel tonally inconsistent. When it comes to the action, meh, it's passable, but nothing special. There's also the issue of length. Did this really need to be 2 and a half hours?

Now this gripe is the main contributor to what warrants a rewatch: that being the storytelling. The basic premise is easy to follow, but somewhere from the 2nd to final act it devolves into an overly-intricate mess. There's nothing wrong with intricacy mind you, as there's many movies I love that have that nature. But there comes a point where if it's overdone, things will spiral out of control and, not only leave viewers un-engaged, but also bored and disinterested in trying to put the pieces together. Because of this, I will be revisiting the film later on. Because perhaps a rewatch will clarify many plot beats for me.

As of right now however, Minority Report left a bad taste in my mouth. There are parts I liked, and many parts I didn't like. It felt like Mission: Impossible(with it's confusing plot) meets Next(with predicting the future, although this is light-years better). Spielberg's direction is peerless as usual with beautiful shots, thrilling action, and groundbreaking ideas. The science fiction elements are pretty clever and forward thinking in Minority Report. This is a movie that blends Spielberg's usual theme of fatherhood with the ethics of law enforcement. Spielberg forces the audience to contend with the futuristic concept of pre-crime: arresting people before they intend to commit a crime. It's a fascinating concept executed in fantastic fashion by Spielberg's high tech machinery and fresh ideas.

Tom Cruise is the star of the show with his highly thoughtful approach to police work. We get to see Cruise take on parenthood, arrests, comedy, investigation, and action sequences alike. He is very compelling as the lead.

Furthermore, I enjoyed Colin Farrell and Max von Sydow's supporting performances a great deal. Their play their official positions with a stern authority. I think the acting in Minority Report is quite underrated. Even Samantha Morton plays the astonished precognitive Agatha with a curious fear that is always believable. Lastly, Peter Stormare delivers a hilarious cameo role with a fervent madness.

On the other hand, a few of the smaller roles all feel too campy and simplistic against the excellent main cast. You see odd characters popping up here and there that do not really fit the hyper serious tone of Minority Report.

Additionally, the run time feels perhaps a half hour too long. You are always engaged in the story until Cruise is offset by some of the weirder side characters who feel like time wasters. Minority Report is approximately 2 and a half hours long, but it feels like 3 hours due to too many extraneous chase scenes and eccentric supporting figures.

Overall, Minority Report is very intriguing with its mystery and investigation. Tom Cruise and Colin Farrell shine. The writing is quite realistic and the futuristic advancements are grounded. Some of the special effects look dated and it is bloated, but Minority Report is a great film.

The two decades preceding Minority Report have been a crucial transitional phase for Hollywood legend, Steven Spielberg; a treasure of the industry with such remarkable and timeless features like Raiders of the Lost Ark, Jaws, E.T. The Extra-Terrestrial and Close Encounters of the Third Kind, taking on extraordinary stories that places its audience in an escaping position, providing the heightened essence of cinema's purity. The Color Purple was the necessary seed that has grown within the filmmaker that would lead him to tackling a humanistic through the most inspiring of tales, one that opens our eyes to our faults and successes throughout history.

Minority Report however takes on a similar ground but this time predicting of what would become of our society; a political drama of 2054 Washington D.C., where the invention and testing of PreCrime have proven successful in the war against homicide, finally creating the secure environment that the government have craved for. The predictions of these crimes are generated from the visions that are formed, and harnessed, by the PreCrime unit and is analysed in finding the necessary clues for its prevention. A premise that manages to display originality, even by the standards of today, that seeing it for the first time is like a breath of fresh air; transporting you to a world that evokes familiarity and innovation that detail in exposition needs not to be heavy to gain understanding.

Spielberg takes on the idea and further emphasises its necessity that requires reflection towards our own conditions; the necessity to morally challenge its government for an innovation that is either contradictory or ambiguous; the undeniable growth and personalisation of consumerism; challenging the concept of fate and its potential diversion through the power of wisdom. Given Spielberg's track record, this could have simply been a replication of Raiders of the Lost Ark on a far more technical and awe-inspiring platform and transport its audience with every breathtaking set-piece. Thankfully, much like Jurassic Park, he has merged the adventure sensibilities of his youth and the thoughtful mindset in his slow transition, leaving the audience with a rewarding experience.

However in his attempt to balance both approaches, it is far from the measured and impactful outcome of Jurassic Park; Minority Report finds itself far too stretched from its two sensibilities, with transitions coming off as far too palpable. Along with this, it arrives at a third act that creates a far too calm transition to its resolution that cushions the impact that the film could have provided if it managed to retain the same sense of encapsulating urgency and tension that filled the veins of its first two acts.

Much like Blade Runner, the film carries a sense of glory in its depiction of technological progression, whilst filling the atmosphere with dire and serious themes. The director dedicates its first 40 minutes as an exhaustive introduction of its world, its social and technological updates, and the key figures that fill it. Spielberg's film has always welcomed the concept of product placement, but unlike many filmmakers (Michael Bay, in particular); it weaves commerciality with narrative progression seamlessly, acting as a necessary element in the shaping of its world.

Since their collaboration in Schindler's List, Janusz Kaminski and Spielberg have developed a strong and understanding relationship; with their films since their initial partnership have taken on a far more stylistic attitude than any of his previous films, excepting the collaborations with Douglas Slocombe. Minority Report screams out in its slick camera movements and noir-inspired lighting that fits perfectly the gritty profession and the tragic personal history of its protagonist. Although difficult to say if this is Kaminski's strongest effort, but it is no doubt an impressive one, and is a large contribution to the film's overall appeal.

Spielberg's 20th feature may be ambitious and technically proficient, but it lacks the desperation of a young filmmaker that places their inner soul with each captured shot; there is a sense of comfort to be found in his direction that may have relied too heavily on the film's screenplay and fruitful experience with computer generated visual effects in its construction. Minority Report may no doubt grow its reputation as years pass and more of its reflective ideas become relevant, but for now it is simply a pleasing entry into Spielberg's prolific filmography.

A superb sci-fi mystery thriller, "Minority Report" is true to Spielberg's adventurous style while making something of itself out of its dark and complex dystopian (or utopian?) premise. 

Based on a short story by Phillip K. Dick, "Minority Report" is set in a future where all murders are predicted by a group of physics called "the precogs", and so there is virtually no crime. Tom Cruise plays John Anderton, the chief of the so-called "PreCrime" task force, and so he's the guy who goes to future murderers' houses and arrests them before they get the chance to kill their intended victim. Of course, there's a twist, and soon enough Anderton is on the run (seriously, Tom Cruise runs in every movie) because the precogs have supposedly predicted that he will murder a guy he's never even heard of in just 36 hours. It's up to him to figure out if he was set up or if, in fact, he is going to be a future murderer, and there are many twists and turns along the way that have us on our toes. 

Perhaps the most spectacular aspect of Minority Report outside of the exciting story is the cinematography, excellent as always by Spielberg regular Janusz Kami?ski. The camera glides smoothly through each shot in a mix of quickly-paced long takes and well-framed still shots that creates an enticing mix of adrenaline and awe that keeps us entertained and interested throughout the heavy 2 hour, 25 minute running time. 

If I have one criticism it's that the music, by John Williams as usual, isn't all that inspired and is at times even distracting. Spielberg hatas will probably not be impressed, either, because it's filled to the brim with his signature pacing, humor, and Indiana-Jones-like set pieces. But for anyone else (i.e. most people who like movies since Spielberg is pretty much synonymous with movies), "Minority Report" is an endlessly enjoyable ride that gets you thinking about Phillip K. Dick's eye-opening themes of predetermination and character without taking you out of the story for one minute.

Based on a Phillip K. Dick story and directed by Steven Spielberg, Minority Report teamed  up a great writer with a great director.

The premise in Minority Report is really original. As usual with Phillip K. Dick, there is a really interesting science fiction concept at the base of the film. It discusses the nature of fate and the future in a complex science fiction setting where the concept of predicting the future is used to prevent crimes before they actually happen, a concept known as determinism. This gives the film a strong base for its tale of herosim as the protagonist of a story which presents the oppurtunity for a compelling thriller story and a strong action adventure. It has the potential to be both, and with directorial work from Steven Spielberg it successfully becomes both. Minority Report succeeds as an interesting science fiction tale and a strong action adventure, even though the fact that it diverts between both means that it is inconsistent in tone and also in pace. 
Minority Report truly is a complex science fiction film, for better and for worse. On the slightly negative side of it, the film goes between scenes with a mix of both explanations of its internal logic which is straight up and to the point and others which stretch out for much longer and slow the pace of the film down quite a bit. I expected as much from a film with such a complex high concept plot, but there just ended up being a few periods of time where things just stretched on for a while. Minority Report is a long film with an interesting central presence, and there is a lot to take in. Steven Spielberg ensures that there is adequate time for viewers to understand everything, but at the same time he ends up rendering the film a long and slow one. It evokes a mixed response because it decreases the full effect of exhileration in the film, but as a whole it does allow viewers to gain an appropriate understanding of all the concepts. As a whole, Minority Report succeeds more as a science fiction thriller than an action film, but it does have some strongly choreographed stunts. The action scenes in Minority Report are great because they capitalise on all the strong visual elements of the film and explore the creativity of the universe well, capitalising on all kinds of advanced technology and weaponry to tell its story.
Minority Report presents a lot of interesting technology as a manner of asserting the scientific future of the film. The design of the world is great because it is futuristic without ignoring the sensibilities of being set in a not-too-distant future which makes it a believable one, and the main theme of the story also reinforces that by exploring a world where governmental use of scientific experimentation paves the way for a breakthrough anti-crime force which gives defence forces control over the future. It is a clever element of totalarian power which is way more subtle than in countless other futuristic films because it is not so much dystopian although in small parts it touches upon the idea. The story is interesting because it starts out as a simple tale with a complex concept, and as the story progresses it becomes more and more complicated. There is a progressively large amount of information to handle, but what starts out as a high concept plot evolves into one which is more imaginative and original than I could have predicted which pays a lot of credibility to the legacy of the late Phillip K. Dick as well as to 	Scott Frank and Jeff Cohen who bring the story to life with a lot of intelligent dialogue and spirit. The one flaw I find in the story comes from the title. The title "Minority Report" refers to a moment when two pre-cogs predict the same vision of the future but the third and strongest of them predicts a different vision of the future. As this vision does not coincide with the majority, it is considered to be a titular Minority Report. It is suspected that the vision of the protagonist committing a crime is incorrect because there is said to be an unseen Minority Report which predicts him to be innocent. But one of the twists in the story is that there is not one for him, and so the fact that the film is titled Minority Report when it is simply one of the most minor elements of the film with little relevance to Captain John Anderton. The concept of a Minority Report is not taken advantage of in a film which is named after it, so that's where some unsatisfactory storytelling comes into play. Still, as a whole, Steven Spielberg brings his sophisticated wisdom as a filmmaker to Minority Report and steps back into the science fiction world once again with the same inspiration to deliver. One of the more intense moments in the film where Captain John Anderton hides himself underwater in an ice cold bathtup while robots search for him is an element that would later be repeated by Steven Spielberg on his following collaboration with Tom Cruise, War of the Worlds.
Minority Report is the first truly notable science fiction neo-noir since the masterful classic Blade Runner which similarly was also based on a Phillip K. Dick story. While the visueal style of the film feels largely familiar for science fiction films, Minority Report incures a grim colour pallette which taints the film with a sense of shadow and darkness, and it reflects the intended universe of the film very nicely. It makes everything look good, and considering that the scenery and production design of the film is already rich with life, it just adds to it. Minority Report benefits from strong production design, powerful visual effects which are moderated nicely so that the film is not overreliant on them. Everything looks good which means that Minority Report works as both a large scale science fiction tale and a small scale neo-noir at the same time, even if it doesn't capitalise on its neo-noir potential or live up to the standard of Blade Runner. 
It didn't take long until I  realised that the musical score of Minority Report could have only been composed by the legendary John Williams. The music is intense and mysterious with a true science fiction feel which evokes some memories to much of his earlier works, even to the greatest work of his career on Star Wars. John Williams teams up with Franz Schubert to create another wonderful musical score for Minority Report, and it gives the film the ideal atmosphere and lays down the effect of it all very well.
But when the film gets to the end, that is when it falters. The ending to the film is a little to uplifting for its own good. After all the complex turmoil, political corruption and violence that has occured in the film, for Minority Report to turn around and give itself what is essentially a fairy tale ending, it just isn't consistent with the complex and twisted dramatic nature of the rest of the feature. Minority Report is a film that tries to be both science fiction and character focused, but the ending to the film gives an unsatisfactory resolution to some of its main characters. A lot of the film feels like some of the character elements are just a mere distraction from the central focus of the film, and the fact that the ending to the film gave everything an overly optimistic finale.
The cast of Minority Report manage to bring strong characters to the feature as well.
Tom Cruise makes a charismatic lead in Minority Report. He combines both a level of professional confidence and humanity into the part so that the focus on his personal demons and his determination is found. His leading charisma is powerful because unlike in War of the Worlds, Steven Spielberg was able to direct Tom Cruise to a well balanced performance. As an amalgamation of both a realistic human being and a professional defence force worker, Tom Cruise carries the charisma of both an action hero and a professional dragged into a complicated situation without going over the top about it, enforcing a sensible level of realism to anchor his efforts.
Max Von Sydow makes a memorable effort in Minority Report. Being one of the world's greatest living actors, Max Von Sydow has an undying legacy of wisdom to him which he easily emits in Minority Report. He delivers all of his lines with a strong understanding of the subject matter which flows from the most intelligent reaches of his mind very organically without a moment of failure. His screen time is small, but memorable because he stands out as one of the strongest cast members in the film. Steven Spielberg is able to get some of the best out of Max Von Sydow, and you can expect nothing less from him.
Colin Farrell does a nice job. His character is intriguing due to the unpredictable nature of him and because Colin Farrell brings a very confident sophistication to the part. He stands strong in the role with a very convincing level of understanding and fearlessness. He deals with the material with a strong level of professional charisma without ever losing sight of his character's intentions ensuring that he is very consistent in the part. Colin Farrell is strong in Minority Report and his interactions with the surrounding cast members boast some strong chemistry.
Lastly, Samantha Morton delivers a strong supporting effort as Agatha Lively. She has a weird part to play as a Pre-cog, but she remainsi adamantly convincing in the part simply because she fits the profile for the part physically and due to the fact that she conveys a lot of mental stress and paranoia due to scientific experimentation that led to her creation. Samantha Morton is very physically involved in the role easily, and her line delivery is perfectly warped for the part.

So although Minority Report has minor narrative flaws and inconsistent focus with pacing, it is a very original science fiction thriller which is both intelligent and visually stellar.

If there's one genre that intrigues me the most, it's easily sci-fi. Whether its the depictions of futuristic societies or technological advances or the intriguing ideas presented, I just really enjoy this film genre. And Minority Report, one of the many films directed by one of my all-time favorite filmmakers, Steven Spielberg, is easily on the list of most intriguing sci-fi in the past decade.

Set in the year 2054, John Anderton (Tom Cruise) is a Washington DC detective who works for the special unit of Precrime, a unit that arrests murderers before actually committing the crime, saving many lives in the process. The process takes place via "precogs", three drugged psychics who specialize in prophesying future events. John's reputation becomes challenges when he is identified as the future killer of a man he never met. With his job on the line, John becomes a fugitive as he races against the clock to prevent his possible crime.

The film also stars Collin Farrell as Precrime pursuer Danny, Samantha Morton as pregog leader Agatha, Lois Smith as the mysterious Dr. Iris Hineman, and Max von Sydow as Precrime director Lamar Burgess.

The thing I respect the most out of the greatest filmmakers is when they step out of their comfort zone. Spielberg uses this format in making Minority Report. Had I not looed at who made the film, I wouldn't have guessed Spielberg made the movie as it's different in style than regular Spielberg greats. And because of that, Minority Report is another excellent Spielberg film that joins the list of some of his all-time best.  

The first thing Spielberg gets right is creating the futuristic world of 2054. Spielberg decided to go the realism route and use as minimum of CGI as possible, and his decision is extremely brilliant. Visually Minority Report is a sight to behold, and the idea of arresting possible killers before committing their crime is an exciting (and sometimes scary) thought. With all the technological advances being a huge boom in society and hearing reports of tighter security in the country (an idea heavily questioned also in this year's Captain America: The Winter Soldier), the ideas presented in Minority Report might end up happening. Whether it will or not, Spielberg has created a thought-provoking futuristic look at our society if we continue on our current path. And Spielberg is a complete genius.

Another thing Spielberg provides really well in the film is how entertaining the film is. Considering its thought-provoking material that raises lots of questions, like with some of the best doses of Spielberg greatness, action plays a big part of Minority Report, and while some of the beatings and punches get a tad ridiculous, it's still extremely fun to watch. It also helps that you got Tom Cruise as your lead star of the film.

Spielberg also succeeds in creating a thrilling modern suspense thriller on top of the thought-provoking sci-fi ideas and elaborate action. Well, when the film involves a man going all out to beat a possible corrupt system, you have to be on the edge of nail biting. There was quite a few plot twists in the film I didn't see coming, and that is definitely something to be proud of. 

Carrying out the greatness of Minority Report by far is it's fantastic acting performance of Tom Cruise. In the opening scenes of the film, I thought Cruise's character was just going to be this extremely bland action hero with absolutely no character development, but I have not been so wrong in early judgments in my life! Cruise nails his complex nature and creates a character that feels absolutely real. As he lost his son due to a murder crime (which caused him to join Precrime), the character of John has to overcome inner demons to get out of his situation. The story arc of facing inner demons is one of my favorites in a motion picture, and though it sounds extremely clichéd for me to say that, usually I enjoy films dealing with that problem, and Tom Cruise nails it.

While the rest of the cast is overshadowed by Cruise's performance, particularly Colin Farrell, who basically a one-dimensional "antagonist", I quite enjoyed their screen presence. The one closest to being as strong as Cruise is Max von Sydow as the suspicious Precrime director, with a performance that's as brilliantly awesome as Robert Redford in the recent Captain America movie! Can't wait to see Sydow appear in the new Star Wars movie.

Like the majority of Spielberg's works, the film is scored by legend John Williams, and like always, Williams' score is beast! Similar to Spielberg's unique structure of the film, Williams uses that to his advantage, creating a very intense and another unforgettable music experience that's as intense as the scores of Bernard Herrmann! 

It's certainly not perfect, as it has the occasional plot-holes (such as Tom Cruise managing to get past security headquarters while being pursued by federal agents), but Minority Report joins the list of unforgettable Spielberg. The sci-fi ideas of mind control and predicting the future is thought-provoking, the action and suspense are extremely intense and pulse-pounding, and Tom Cruise gives a truly magnificent performance. I wouldn't call myself a nerd of Minority Report, but I can say that I was extremely immersed with another great work from Spielberg.

Minority Report asks a fascinating question. If it were possible to catch a murderer before he or she committed the crime - did they still commit a crime? The year is 2054 and through the use of three special psychics called 'Precogs', law enforcement officers are provided glimpses of a murder before it actually occurs. With the information they gather they are then dispatched to prevent the crime from happening. The intent to kill though is still a crime, and even though the murder was stopped, the would be killer is still hauled away by the police. The system is tested though when one of its strongest supporters, John Anderton (Tom Cruise) starts to investigate a Precog vision that labels him as the killer.

The central question is covered very well in Spielberg's film. Tom Cruise delivers a powerful performance as the talented, yet troubled Pre-crime detective. He's also very ably supported by Colin Farrell as a Department of Justice stooge, and Samatha Morton as the most talented Precog, Agatha. What impressed me the most about this film was the technology on display. Everything the characters touched and interacted with seemed really well researched and completely plausible. From the 3D home projector system, to the large screen the detectives control with hand gestures when investigating Precog visions. There was nothing in this film that seemed to far fetched or over the top, and that attention to detail created a great foundation to properly explore the stories central theme.

The conflict is introduced when Cruise finds out that he is the next expected murderer. Tom Cruise is back in another action flick -- except it's a lot more than that, as Minority Report is set in 2054. John Anderton (Cruise) is the head of a special police force called Precrime, in which psychics called precogs foresee a murder happening in the future and the police arrest the perpetrator before it happens. This program, of which Lamar Burgess (Von Sydow) is the head, has been widely successful in Washington DC and Virginia, and Burgess is looking to expand the program across the United States. The only glitch? Anderton finds an inconsistency in one of the murder files, unlocking secrets that are meant to be kept from the world. This leads to him being framed, and the plot then thickens.

I loved Tom Cruise in this film. His character is seen to be very unstable since his child was kidnapped a few years earlier, and Tom Cruise does an amazing job portraying such a broken character. Colin Farrell plays Danny Witwer, a Department of Justice agent, who is looking to take Anderton down, and he does a great job of this as well. I want to talk more about his character but I don't want to give any spoilers!

Now on to the concept. I loved the idea of the future. The effects were pretty good for 2002, and the ideas were what made me so interested. First was the whole precrime idea in itself, the first scene is of them preventing a murder, and it was probably the best part in the whole movie. Tom Cruise looks through the images the precogs see on a floating computer hologram thing, and directs it with his lit up gloves, and it's just amazing to watch. The next thing was the cars and the roads, which moved left, right, up and down. Spielberg does a great job of making all the new technology seem practical for the future, and explains it to the audience through a policeman explaining it to Farrell's character.

There were also some things that didn't work for me in the film. The first thing would be some of the dialogue. There were some cheesy one-liners that could have been totally omitted, and which brought the film down a notch. The second thing would be Agatha, played by Samantha Morton. I liked the character and the idea, but there are scenes where she foresees that something bad will happen and screams. It wasn't even a womanly scream it was a deep weird scream that I also thought was a little unnecessary.

For ratings, I would like to give this film 4 stars. I loved the themes and ideas it brought forth, and the way it was shot was also amazing, but there were little aspects that didn't appeal to me.

The movie pulls out the debate of freewill. Is freewill truly freewill if my future actions are known before hand. The Bible makes us know that God knows the end from the beginning, and that he hand crafted us, so those that mean we have freewill or are we just a piece of a big puzzle.

Minority Report answers that question by saying even if the future is known, the path can still be changed it is just a matter of determination. Set 50 years into the future, this classic is about a future where the criminals are arrested before they commit the crime.

The story itself was written by Philip K. Dick and it was supposed to be a sequel to the 1990 Dick adaptation of the movie Total Recall, which starred Arnold Schwarzenegger. When the sequel was not forth coming, novelist Jon Cohen was hired in 1997 to adapt the story for a potential film version. Cruise got a hold of the script and passed it on to Spielberg, with the hope that they will make a movie together from it. Spielberg liked the script but decided it need to be improved upon and so Cohen did another draft and Cruise and Spielberg decided to go in together to make the movie, both deciding not to take any money upfront but to share a percentage of the gross profit.

Boasting of high tech graphics and CGI, this futuristic film looked certain, like if God willing we are all here in the next 50 years that movie looked like what it will be.

The movie plot centers on the Lead Character John Anderton. In April 2054, Captain John Anderton (Tom Cruise) is chief of the Washington, D.C. PreCrime police force. Thanks to their proficiency and effectiveness and intense use future visions generated by three "precogs", (these precogs are mutated humans with precognitive abilities) to stop murders, the city of Washington has been murder free for 6 years. The moment the murderers think it up in their mind this precogs sends a visual message and the culprit is picked up before the crime is committed.

Things change for Anderton soon enough, that while the system is being audited by Danny Witwer (Colin Farrell), the precogs predict that Anderton will murder a man named Leo Crow in 36 hours.

Anderton is surprised because he knows no Leo Crow, so now breaks loose and is on the run stealing one of the precogs in order to help clear his name.
